title: The Cloisters

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of tempera on board.

description: Andrew Wyeth often sought to capture his emotional response to an intriguing place by honing, refining, and crystallizing his initial impressions into hushed, haunting final compositions. The Cloisters depicts a small, empty room at the Ephrata Cloister, located near Lancaster, Pennsylvania, about 50 miles from Wyeth’s home in Chadds Ford. It was the seat of the German Seventh-day Baptists, an early American religious colony that had disbanded in 1934 and was being restored as a historic landmark when Wyeth visited with his aunt Elizabeth in 1949. Wyeth’s early studies portrayed Elizabeth in the room, but he eliminated her figure and increasingly abstracted the space to focus on the play of light against the muted brown walls. The bird, a chalk sculpture of the type produced by residents of the Ephrata Cloister, stands as a slightly surreal evocation of the history of the colony and Elizabeth’s one-time presence in the scene.
inscriptions: Signed recto, lower left, in dark brown pigment: Andrew Wyeth
publication_history: Carnegie Institute, Painting in the United States, exh. cat. (Pittsburg: Carnegie Institution, 1949), cat. 170, plate 17 (ill.). Institute of Contemporary Arts, Symbolic Realism in American Painting, 1940–1950, exh. cat. (London: The Institute of Contemporary Arts, 1950), 11, cat. 38, fig. 15 (ill.). Paintings and Drawings by Andrew Wyeth, exh. cat. (Manchester, NH, and Rockland, ME: Currier Gallery and William A. Farnsworth Library and Art Museum, 1951), 16, cat. 20 (ill.). Andrew Wyeth, pamphlet for exhibition (Delaware: Wilmington Society of the Fine Arts, 1957), cat. 23. Ernest W. Watson, “Mood, a chapter from “Composition in Landscape and Still Life,” reprinted in American Artist (Oct. 1959): 33 (ill). Andrew Wyeth: Tempera, Water Colors and Drawings, exh. cat. (Buffalo, NY: Buffalo Fine Arts Academy, Albright-Knox Art Gallery, 1962), 9, cat. 11. Andrew Wyeth: Temperas, Watercolors, Dry Brush, Drawings, 1938 into 1960, exh. cat. (Philadelphia: Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, 1966), (ill.). C.C.C., “Andrew Wyeth Exhibition,” Calendar of the Art Institute of Chicago 61, 2 (March 1967): 7 (ill.). “Accessions of American and Canadian Museums: October-December, 1966,” The Art Quarterly 30, 1 (1967): 77, 81 (ill.). Andrew Wyeth, exh. cat. (Boston: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, 1970), no. 13. Wanda Corn, Andrew Wyeth: The Man, His Art, and His Audience (Ph.D., New York University, Fine Arts, 1974), 103 (ownership mentioned, not illustrated). Jaan Kangilaski, “Cover,” JAMA: Journal of the American Medical Association (Jan 5, 1976): cover image, 4 (ill.). Richard Meryman, Andrew Wyeth: A Secret Life (New York: HarperCollins Publishers,1996), 242, 250 (ownership mentioned, not illustrated). Judith A. Barter et al., American Modernism at the Art Institute of Chicago, From World War I to 1955 (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago/Yale University Press, 2009), cat. 168.
exhibition_history:
Pittsburgh, The Carnegie Institute, Painting in the United States, Oct. 13–Dec. 11, 1949, no. 207, pl. 17.

London, England, the Institute of Contemporary Arts, Symbolic Realism in American Painting, July 18–Aug. 18, 1950, no. 38.

Manchester, New Hampshire, The Currier Gallery of Art, Paintings and Drawings by Andrew Wyeth, July 7–Aug. 4, 1951; Rockland, Maine, The William A. Farnsworth Library and Art Museum, Aug. 10–Sept. 8, 1951, no. 20, illus.

Wilmington, Delaware, the Wilmington Society of the Fine Arts, Andrew Wyeth, Jan. 7–Feb. 3, 1957, no. 23. 

Buffalo, New York, the Albright–Knox Art Gallery, Andrew Wyeth, Nov. 2–Dec. 9, 1962, no. 11.

Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, Andrew Wyeth, Temperas, Watercolors, Dry Brush, Drawings, 1938 into 1966; Baltimore Museum of Art, Dec. 11, 1966–Jan. 22, 1967; Whitney Museum of American Art, Feb. 6–Apr. 12, 1967; Art Institute of Chicago, Apr. 21–June 4, 1967, illus.

Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, July 16–Sept. 6, 1970, no. 13, illus.
provenance_text: The artist; sold to Lincoln Kirstein, NY, 1949 [Carnegie Institute 1949, no. 170]; sold to Joseph Verner Reed (1902–1973), NY, by 1957 [Wilmington Society of the Fine Arts 1957, no. 23; Meryman 1996, 242]; sold, the American Pageant of Fashion and the Arts, NY, Dec. 29, 1963 [on view in Knoedler Gallery, NY, Dec. 1963]. Wildenstein and Co., NY, by June 1966, sold to Helen Regenstein (Mrs. Joseph Regenstein; born Asher, 1896–1982), Chicago, Aug. 1966 [correspondence from Louis Goldenberg, Wildenstein and Co., to Mrs. Joseph Regenstein in curatorial object file, Arts of the Americas]; given to the Art Institute of Chicago, Dec. 22, 1966.
